docs.lead_paragraph: The wedding day was set, guests invited, and Linda Santarelli and Teddy Roland mused about a beach ceremony near their home in Loxahatchee, Fla. Then they learned of a new state law giving couples a marriage-license discount if they took a marital education class. More for the information than the price break, they said, they took a four-hour class last spring, a month before the wedding. By the end of it, they were convinced they were moving too fast.

headline.main: States Declare War On Divorce Rates, Before Any 'I Dos'

docs.abstract: Growing number of states require or encourage engaged couples to take marital education course out of concern about high social and economic costs of divorce; other initiatives include Wisconsin's hiring of 'marriage czar' to urge clergy to set requirements for engaged couples, and Arkansas's exploration of tax credit for couples taking marital course; Utah includes marital skills in high school curriculums, and Florida makes marital course high school graduation requirement; critics of such initiatives say government is meddling in marriage; close to half of marriages end in divorce; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The wedding day was set, guests invited, and Linda Santarelli and Teddy Roland mused about a beach ceremony near their home in Loxahatchee, Fla.    Then they learned of a new state law giving couples a marriage-license discount if they took a marital...

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton recently called on Congress to raise aid for international family planning by $169 million next year, bringing the total to $541 million in the 2001 budget. That substantial increase, coming after years of cuts, would merely restore funding to 1995 levels. Far more is needed. Nearly 600,000 women die annually from complications of pregnancy and childbirth. Many of them could be saved by services that help women avoid unintended pregnancies. Mr. Clinton is also calling on Congress to abolish the pernicious restriction on advocacy activities that was imposed on foreign family planning organizations as part of a deal last year to get Congress to pay back dues owed to the United Nations. Under longstanding law, no United States government funds may be used by foreign agencies for either abortion services or for lobbying on abortion policy.
docs.abstract: Editorial calls for increased United States aid for international family planning; backs bill to end curb on abortion advocacy activities of foreign family planning groups that get United States funding
